team11.core.other

Class Shot

  • java.lang.Object
    • team11.core.other.Shot

  • public class Shot
extends java.lang.Object
    Provides a shot data structure to hold the initial focus point, the change in the X and Y coordinates to drag to, and the times to both shot the bird and tap the screen.
    Author:
    Chris N. Hartley (cnhartle@calpoly.edu)

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Shot()
      Constructor for an instance of the shot class with all values set to zero.
      Shot(int x, int y, int dx, int dy, long shootTime)
      Constructor for an instance of the shot with the specified focus point, at (x, y), the change in the X-coordinate to drag to, the change in the Y-coordinate to drag to, and the offset time to shoot this particular shot at.
      Shot(int x, int y, int dx, int dy, long shootTime, long tapTime)
      Constructor for an instance of the shot with the specified focus point, at (x, y), the change in the X-coordinate to drag to, the change in the Y-coordinate to drag to, the offset time to shoot this particular shot at, and the delay offset from the shot time to simulate a tap on the screen.
      Shot(int x, int y, long shootTime, long tapTime)
      Constructor for an instance of the shot with the specified focus point, at (x, y), the offset time to shoot this particular shot at, and the delay offset from the shot time to simulate a tap on the screen.
      Shot(java.awt.Point pt, int dx, int dy, long shootTime)
      Constructor for an instance of the shot with the specified focus point, pt, the change in the X-coordinate to drag to, the change in the Y-coordinate to drag to, and the offset time to shoot this particular shot at.
      Shot(java.awt.Point pt, int dx, int dy, long shootTime, long tapTime)
      Constructor for an instance of the shot with the specified focus point, pt,the change in the X-coordinate to drag to, the change in the Y-coordinate to drag to, the offset time to shoot this particular shot at, and the delay offset from the shot time to simulate a tap on the screen.
      Shot(java.awt.Point pt, long shootTime, long tapTime)
      Constructor for an instance of the shot with the specified focus point, pt, the offset time to shoot this particular shot at, and the delay offset from the shot time to simulate a tap on the screen.
      Shot(Shot anotherShot)
      Constructor for an instance of the shot based on the specified shot.

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      int getDeltaX()
      Returns the change in the X-coordinates from the focus point to calculate the release point from.
      int getDeltaY()
      Returns the change in the Y-coordinates from the focus point to calculate the release point from.
      java.awt.Point getFocusPoint()
      Returns the focus point which denotes the starting mouse position in game to begin the mouse dragging action for the shot.
      java.awt.Point getReleasePoint()
      Returns the release point based on the focus point and the changes in both X- and Y-coordinates.
      long getShootTime()
      Returns the time to perform the shot at in milliseconds.
      static java.util.Comparator<Shot> getShootTimeComparator()
      Returns a Comparator for the type Shot used to order the shots based on their shooting times.
      long getTapTime()
      Returns the time, in milliseconds, to simulate the tap action at in game while firing a bird.
      int getX()
      Returns the X-coordinate of the focus point which denotes the starting mouse position in game to begin the mouse dragging action for the shot.
      int getY()
      Returns the Y-coordinate of the focus point which denotes the starting mouse position in game to begin the mouse dragging action for the shot.

      Sets the change in the X-coordinates from the focus point to calculate the release point.

      Sets the change in the Y-coordinates from the focus point to calculate the release point.

      Sets the time to perform the shot at in milliseconds.

      Sets the time, in milliseconds, to simulate the tap action at in game while firing a bird.

      Sets the Y-coordinate of the focus point which denotes the starting mouse position in game to begin the mouse dragging action for the shot.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Shot

        public Shot()
        Constructor for an instance of the shot class with all values set to zero. This is the same as calling the Shot(0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0) constructor.

      • Shot

        public Shot(Shot anotherShot)
        Constructor for an instance of the shot based on the specified shot. This effectively clones all of the parameters of the anotherShot into this new instance.
        Parameters:
        anotherShot - another Shot to capture the parameters from.

      • Shot

        public Shot(java.awt.Point pt,
    long shootTime,
    long tapTime)
        Constructor for an instance of the shot with the specified focus point, pt, the offset time to shoot this particular shot at, and the delay offset from the shot time to simulate a tap on the screen.
        Parameters:
        pt - the focus Point to start the shot at.
        shootTime - the offset time in milliseconds to shoot at.
        tapTime - the delay from the shoot time in milliseconds to tap at.
        See Also:
        Point

      • Shot

        public Shot(int x,
    int y,
    long shootTime,
    long tapTime)
        Constructor for an instance of the shot with the specified focus point, at (x, y), the offset time to shoot this particular shot at, and the delay offset from the shot time to simulate a tap on the screen.
        Parameters:
        x - the int X-coordinate for the focus point to start the shot at.
        y - the int Y-coordinate for the focus point to start the shot at.
        shootTime - the offset time in milliseconds to shoot at.
        tapTime - the delay from the shoot time in milliseconds to tap at.

      • Shot

        public Shot(java.awt.Point pt,
    int dx,
    int dy,
    long shootTime)
        Constructor for an instance of the shot with the specified focus point, pt, the change in the X-coordinate to drag to, the change in the Y-coordinate to drag to, and the offset time to shoot this particular shot at.
        Parameters:
        pt - the focus Point to start the shot at.
        dx - the int change in X-coordinates to release the shot from.
        dy - the int change in Y-coordinates to release the shot from.
        shootTime - the offset time in milliseconds to shoot at.
        See Also:
        Point

        public Shot(int x,
    int y,
    int dx,
    int dy,
    long shootTime,
    long tapTime)
        Constructor for an instance of the shot with the specified focus point, at (x, y), the change in the X-coordinate to drag to, the change in the Y-coordinate to drag to, the offset time to shoot this particular shot at, and the delay offset from the shot time to simulate a tap on the screen.

        tapTime - the delay from the shoot time in milliseconds to tap at.

      • getFocusPoint

        public java.awt.Point getFocusPoint()
        Returns the focus point which denotes the starting mouse position in game to begin the mouse dragging action for the shot.
        Returns:
        the Point for the location of the focus point to start the shot at.
        See Also:
        Point

      • getReleasePoint

        public java.awt.Point getReleasePoint()
        Returns the release point based on the focus point and the changes in both X- and Y-coordinates. Effectively, this is equivalent to: Point release = new Point(focus.x + deltaX, focus.y + deltaY)
        Returns:
        the Point for the location of the release point.
        See Also:
        Point

      • getShootTime

        public long getShootTime()
        Returns the time to perform the shot at in milliseconds.
        Returns:
        the time, in milliseconds, to fire the shot at.

      • setShootTime

        public void setShootTime(long shootTime)
        Sets the time to perform the shot at in milliseconds.
        Parameters:
        shootTime - the long time in milliseconds to shot at.

      • getTapTime

        public long getTapTime()
        Returns the time, in milliseconds, to simulate the tap action at in game while firing a bird.
        Returns:
        the long time in milliseconds to tap at.

      • setTapTime

        public void setTapTime(long tapTime)
        Sets the time, in milliseconds, to simulate the tap action at in game while firing a bird.
        Parameters:
        tapTime - the delay from the shoot time in milliseconds to tap at.
